articles.title: ‘Do not give up on children’: Displaced by violence, a Haitian girl finds hope at school
articles.summary: A teenage Haitian girl who was forced to flee her home in Haiti’s capital, Port-au-Prince, due to gang violence has urged adults not to “give up on children.”
articles.content:
A teenage Haitian girl who was forced to flee her home in Haiti’s capital, Port-au-Prince, due to gang violence has urged adults not to “give up on children.”

Thirteen-year-old Dieussika was living peacefully with her family before armed violence and insecurity forced them to flee.

“We had to leave our home, and my sister almost died because of her asthma,” she said.

Haiti remains firmly in the grip of a security crisis as gangs battle for control of territory in the capital and beyond.

Insecurity has caused the displacement of hundreds of thousands of people which has added to the humanitarian and economic crises the country is grappling with.

Conflict, displacement, poverty and insecurity have converged to make learning nearly impossible for hundreds of thousands of Haitian children.

During the 2024–2025 school year, many schools were directly impacted by violence, with more than 1,600 closed and dozens occupied by armed groups.

In overcrowded shelters and displacement sites, children lack access to textbooks, learning materials as well as qualified teachers.

© UNOCHA/Giles Clarke Families find refuge inside a school building in Port-au-Prince, Haiti.

Temporary homes

Dieussika’s family was forced to live in a number of temporary locations but life remained difficult. “There are diseases, insects that bite… but despite everything, I wanted to continue going to school,” she says.

In one site for displaced people, she was able to resume her studies thanks to catch-up classes organized by UNICEF.

Today, she dreams of becoming someone important in society to help children and raise awareness among young people about rejecting armed violence.

School as a lifeline

One night, heavy rain soaked her belongings, destroying her books and clothes. Yet, Dieussika spent the entire night drying them, determined not to give up on her studies.

“School means so much to me. Without education, my dream would be lost,” she said.

© UNICEF/Herold Joseph Dieussika shows her family her school work.

Her favorite subjects are French and maths, and she said she feels pride every time she can bring good grades home to her parents.

Thanks to five months of catch-up classes with the support of Education Cannot Wait, a UN fund for education in emergencies, Dieussika was able to take her exams and return to school.

“I had lost hope, but these classes gave me confidence again. We also received vocational training in crochet, leatherwork, and cosmetology. It was an incredible opportunity,” she recalled proudly.

No dreams fulfilled without education

At school, Dieussika actively participates in her mathematics class, encouraged and supported by her teacher. She wants to put an end to the hardship her household faces and show her family that they too can follow in her footsteps.

“I want to become someone important to help people. Without school, we cannot achieve our dreams,” she said with determination.

Her message to adults and decision-makers is clear and moving: “Do not give up on children. Love them even more and give them opportunities to learn and dream.”

Many adolescent girls like Dieussika drop out of school due to safety concerns, caregiving responsibilities or the absence of menstrual hygiene materials.

Fleeing violence couldn’t stop Dieussika’s love for learning | UNICEF Haiti

Thanks to the UN and its work with the Haitian authorities and partners, educational and psychosocial support programmes have reached more than 17,500 children, including 10,500 girls.

For Dieussika, as for so many others, these programmes represent more than education they are a lifeline, a chance to turn fear into confidence and ambition.

articles.personality_title: Haitian girl displaced by violence finds hope through education
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**  
Haiti is facing a serious security crisis, with gangs fighting for control in the capital, Port-au-Prince. This violence has forced many families to leave their homes. Schools have closed, and many children struggle to continue learning. 

**What happened**  
Thirteen-year-old Dieussika and her family had to flee their home because of gang violence. Despite living in temporary shelters with difficult conditions, she kept going to school. Thanks to catch-up classes organized by UNICEF and support from the UN fund Education Cannot Wait, she was able to take exams and continue her education. 

**Impact**  
Dieussika’s story shows how education can give children strength and hope even in hard times. The classes helped her regain confidence and learn new skills like crochet and cosmetology. More than 17,500 children, including many girls, have received similar support, showing that education is a vital lifeline for displaced children in Haiti. 

**What's next step**  
The UN and partners will keep offering educational and psychosocial programs to help more children affected by violence. These efforts aim to give young people the chance to dream and build better futures despite ongoing challenges. 

**One-sentence takeaway**  
Despite violence and displacement, education programs are helping Haitian children like Dieussika regain hope and continue learning.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une fille haïtienne déplacée par la violence trouve de l'espoir grâce à l'éducation
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**  
Haïti traverse une grave crise sécuritaire avec des gangs qui s'affrontent dans la capitale, Port-au-Prince. Cette violence force de nombreuses familles à fuir leur maison. Les écoles ferment et beaucoup d'enfants ont du mal à poursuivre leur apprentissage. 

**Ce qui s'est passé**  
Dieussika, 13 ans, et sa famille ont dû quitter leur domicile à cause de la violence des gangs. Malgré des conditions difficiles dans des abris temporaires, elle a continué à aller à l'école. Grâce à des cours de rattrapage organisés par l'UNICEF et au soutien du fonds de l'ONU Education Cannot Wait, elle a pu passer ses examens et poursuivre sa scolarité. 

**Impact**  
L'histoire de Dieussika montre comment l'éducation peut donner force et espoir aux enfants même dans des moments difficiles. Les cours lui ont redonné confiance et permis d'apprendre de nouveaux savoir-faire comme le crochet et la cosmétologie. Plus de 17 500 enfants, dont beaucoup de filles, ont reçu un soutien similaire, montrant que l'éducation est une bouée de sauvetage essentielle pour les enfants déplacés en Haïti. 

**Prochaine étape**  
L'ONU et ses partenaires continueront à offrir des programmes éducatifs et psychosociaux pour aider davantage d'enfants touchés par la violence. Ces efforts visent à donner aux jeunes la chance de rêver et de construire un avenir meilleur malgré les défis. 

**Message clé en une phrase**  
Malgré la violence et les déplacements, les programmes éducatifs aident des enfants haïtiens comme Dieussika à retrouver espoir et à continuer d'apprendre.
articles.personality_title_es: Niña haitiana desplazada por la violencia encuentra esperanza a través de la educación
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**  
Haití enfrenta una grave crisis de seguridad, con pandillas que luchan por el control en la capital, Puerto Príncipe. Esta violencia ha obligado a muchas familias a abandonar sus hogares. Las escuelas han cerrado y muchos niños tienen dificultades para seguir aprendiendo. 

**Qué pasó**  
Dieussika, una niña de 13 años, y su familia tuvieron que huir de su casa por la violencia de las pandillas. A pesar de vivir en refugios temporales con condiciones difíciles, ella siguió yendo a la escuela. Gracias a clases de recuperación organizadas por UNICEF y el apoyo del fondo de la ONU Education Cannot Wait, pudo presentar exámenes y continuar su educación. 

**Impacto**  
La historia de Dieussika muestra cómo la educación puede dar fuerza y esperanza a los niños incluso en tiempos difíciles. Las clases le ayudaron a recuperar la confianza y a aprender nuevas habilidades como crochet y cosmetología. Más de 17,500 niños, incluidas muchas niñas, han recibido apoyo similar, demostrando que la educación es un salvavidas esencial para los niños desplazados en Haití. 

**Próximos pasos**  
La ONU y sus socios continuarán ofreciendo programas educativos y psicosociales para ayudar a más niños afectados por la violencia. Estos esfuerzos buscan dar a los jóvenes la oportunidad de soñar y construir un futuro mejor a pesar de los desafíos. 

**Conclusión en una frase**  
A pesar de la violencia y el desplazamiento, los programas educativos están ayudando a niños haitianos como Dieussika a recuperar la esperanza y continuar aprendiendo.
